> >  > > I'm trying to get JUnit to work happily with Ant within WSAD

(AntRunner.java:234)

why.  I
> > have
> >  > > the junit.jar in my Classpath.
> >  >
> >  > Which classpath? WSAD project build path? Ant compile-time 
class
> > path?
> >  > Ant run-time class path?
> >  >
> >  > I suspect you are building your application with WSAD, then 
running
> > the
> >  > tests with Ant. That could be the problem: WSAD 5 ships with 
JUnit
> > 3.7
> >  > and with Ant you are likely using JUnit 3.8.1. Look in the WSAD
> > plugins
> >  > folder for junit.jar and see which version it is. Change your 
WSAD
> >  > project to use the same junit.jar as you use with Ant -- 
preferably
> > by
> >  > creating a WSAD Classpath Variable.
> >  > --
> >  > J. B. Rainsberger,
> >  > Diaspar Software Services
> >  > http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
> >  > Let's write software that people understand
> > 
> > J.B., thank you for replying.  How do I modify the WSAD Project
> > Path?  I am running this through the XML Perspective, and when you
> > left-click on the project and choose properties, the only real
> > configuration you can do is add other referenced projects.  
Nothing
> > about classpath or adding external jars.
> 
> That's in the Library and Export/Order tabs of the Project 
Properties | 
> Java Build Path dialog. Use the online help that ships with WSAD, 
as 
> it's very well written!
> 
> > I run the Ant script in verbose mode, and I see what you're kind 
of
> > eluding to, that I'm pointing to the wrong version of JUnit.  I 
see
> > the full classpath in the system out, which has no reference to
> > JUnit, and then I see the following lines:
> > 
> > <output>
> > Implicitly adding
> > C:\bin\WebSphere\Studio\eclipse\plugins\org.junit_3.7.0
> > \junit.jar;D:\Ant\apache-ant-1.6.0\lib\ant-
launcher.jar;D:\Ant\apache-
> > ant-1.6.0\lib\ant.jar;D:\Ant\apache-ant-1.6.0\lib\ant-junit.jar to
> > CLASSPATH
> > Using CLASSPATH
> > 
D:\Ant\test;C:\bin\WebSphere\Studio\eclipse\plugins\org.junit_3.7.0
> > \junit.jar;D:\Ant\apache-ant-1.6.0\lib\ant-
launcher.jar;D:\Ant\apache-
> > ant-1.6.0\lib\ant.jar;D:\Ant\apache-ant-1.6.0\lib\ant-junit.jar
> > Using CLASSPATH
> > 
D:\Ant\test;C:\bin\WebSphere\Studio\eclipse\plugins\org.junit_3.7.0
> > \junit.jar;D:\Ant\apache-ant-1.6.0\lib\ant-
launcher.jar;D:\Ant\apache-
> > ant-1.6.0\lib\ant.jar;D:\Ant\apache-ant-1.6.0\lib\ant-junit.jar
> > </output>
> > 
> > Since that's the first appearance of a JUnit jar, I'm assuming 
that's
> > the one it's using.  I don't know how these jars get implicitly
> > added, or how I can change them.  I'm a newbie to Ant/JUnit/WSAD
> > combination, can you tell? :)
> 
> The error message above indicates that junit.jar is not in the 
CLASSPATH 
> at all. It needs to be in the CLASSPATH of the JVM that runs your 
tests, 
> so you need to add it yourself. For the <junit> or <java> task that 
runs 
> your tests, add junit.jar to the classpath using the <classpath> 
tag. 
> CHeck out the Ant manual for more information.
> 
> It's not enough for Ant to have JUnit in its CLASSPATH... your test-
run 
> JVM needs it, too, and those JVMs are separate.
> 
> Good luck.
> -- 
> J. B. Rainsberger,
> Diaspar Software Services
